General interval comment: Brown pelagic silt-mud. Some coarser sand grains. Moderately well sorted.
Lighter brown color, gradational contact.
Continued from previous section
Yellowish color from oxidized ultramafics, which form the sandy fraction of the sediment. Looks like a clast of serpentinized UM that weathered in place.
Similar to section from o-13 cm
Small 2 cm pebble at top of layer. Probably highly altered and oxidized UM rock.
Clast comments: Highly altered UM rock - probably. Pale orange yellow, no visible grains, thin veins on margins.

General interval comment: MBIO
Coasrse sand size grains of serpentine.
Coasrse sand size grains of serpentine
One large UM clast comprises bottom half of CC.
Clast comments: Single large clast of black highly altered UM rock.

General interval comment: strongly weathered ultramafic clast
Clasts are dominantly serpentinized ultramafic rocks
Clast is crosscut by oxidized serpentine veins
Multiple serpentine veins. Some opx are altered to bastite serpentine.
Some calcite veins. 1-3 cm in size
Blue sandy clay with granules of black serpentine and orange oxidized serpentine. One clast about 8 mm, others all 1-2 mm.
Clast comments: Single oxidized orange clast; small granules of orange and black serpentine.

General interval comment: Five pieces >2 cm, several small pieces. Most peridotite but one breccia with carbonate cement may have volcanics.
One large piece of partially serpentinized harzburgite cut by thin serpentine veins and two wider veins with dark gray haloes. Relatively fresh - may be less than 50% serpentine.

One large piece of partially serpentinized harzburgite cut by one wide serpentine vein (2 mm + 4 mm dark gray halo) and many thin veins. The wide vein is dark black - may be rich in magnetite. Relatively fresh - may be less than 50% serpentine.
Large piece of pyroxene-rich dunite. Dark black color, with paler Opx. One large light area may be giant pyroxene.
Two large pieces of dunite, pyroxene rich. Bottom of piece may grade into harzburgite. Pieces fit together, originally one piece. Thin serpetine veins.
Small piece of pyroxene poor harzburgite.
Single piece of harzburgite, may grade into dunite on one edge.
Single piece of serpentinized harzburgite, cut by thin serpentine veins. Appears to have faint foliation defined by thin shear bands.
Single piece of harzburgite, may grade into dunite on one edge.
Two pieces of meta basalt. Pale greenish grey. Fine plag laths with pyroxene and glass(?). Small vesicles up to 2 mm filled with blue clay - saponite? Very low metamorphic grade.

Single piece of pale grey metabasalt, with clearly visible intergranular to intersertal textures. Small saponite filled vesicles. One side of clast is darker grey, looks like fresh unaltered center of the cobble. Concentric weathering rinds support this interpretation.
Single piece of polymict breccia containing clasts of UM rock, vesicular volcanics, green and white serpentine chips, non-vesicular basalts. Several clasts up to 2 cm, most granules (<0.5 cm).
Single piece of polymict breccia with clasts of UM rock and volcanic rock. Volcanic clasts are dominant; up to 2-3 cm in size. One UM clast 3 cm. Many small granules.
Single piece of polymict breccia; clasts less well defined - may be very large. Mostly pale green meta basalts.
Single piece of polymict breccia. Clasts to 2 cm; mostly meta basalt.
Single piece of polymict breccia. Clasts not well defined - matrix is more crystalline. Clasts mostly 1 cm across. Matrix is fine grained material similar to the clasts.
Single piece of UM rock, with plumose sprays of fibrous mineral associated with pyroxene - may be antigorite.
Four piece - 3 ultramafic rocks and one meta volcanic.
Described in intrusive mantle tab.
Described in intrusive mantle tab.
Single piece of polymict breccia; clasts less well defined - may be very large. Mostly pale green meta basalts.
Single piece of polymict breccia; clasts less well defined - may be very large. Mostly pale green meta basalts.
Large piece of pyroxene-rich dunite to harzburgite. Dark black color, with paler Opx. One large light area may be giant pyroxene.
Pieces of pyroxene-rich dunite to harzburgite. Dark black color, with paler Opx.
One large piece of partially serpentinized harzburgite cut by one thin serpentine vein. ~70 % serpentinization, single Px clasts
Single piece of serpentinized dunite

General interval comment: Oxydized carbonate breccia with serpentinized UM clasts. An isolated white sub-rounded clast (diameter: 2 mm) observed, that may be brucite but certainly not carbonate
4 pieces of really oxidized UM thinny (<1 cm) clasts
9 serpentinized hazburgite clasts from 1 to 3 cemtimeter-thick - could be fresh

Alternating layers with darker and lighter colors: light brown, black, dark brown. Black layer slightly coarser grained. Small blob of tan sediment. Bioturbated - burrows cross darker/lighter layers. Below the hard ground is softer brown silt, faint bedding traces, tilted - may be drilling disturbance.
Layer contains lightere colored intraclasts of fine silt - possibly ash rich.
Light colored very ash and nannofossil rich layer. Tan color. Distinct from layers above and below.
IW
Lower part of section is well consolidated, upper part may be broken by drilling
Four colored beds: upper is brown, then redddish, then light brown, then lower is brown again. Bedding is wavy and layers vary in thickness - may be drilling disturbed.
Very good looking layer with dark brown and light tan material, broken up to form intraclasts of one within the other. This is not drilling induced by seems to be sedimentary structure.
MENA
Upper 2 cm fairly massive, lower 2 cm is very finely laminated.
Much bioturbation, grades from gray brown to light brown. One thin 5 mm thick layer of black material near center of unit (at 8 cm offset)
Broken up in bottom of core catcher, can't see bedding or structures
Very dark siltstone pieces floating in dark matrix of similar material. Appears to have been broken up by drilling. Bedding in siltstone at varying orientations.
This interval contains numerous silty mudstone with size ranging from granule to pebble. Subdominant oxidized serpentinized ultramafic rocks and manganese nodules.

This interval is composed of two domains: a lithified brown siltstone and unconsolidated dark brown silty mud. The boundaries between the two domains are sharp and sub-horizontal. Ultramafic and mafic clasts.
Brecciated, brown and green lithic clasts with pebble size.
This sandstone contains dark brown coarse sandstone and brown fine sandstone. The same material of this sandstone is brecciated due to drilling disturbance between 59 and 64 cm.
MBIO, IW
Soupy drilling disturbance. Dark brown pebble clasts are mudstone.
Partly disturbed by drilling..
Partly disturbed by drilling.
Dark brown clasts at the bottom. Some brown round to subround pebbly lithic clasts.
Fall-in with oxidized ultramafic clasts.
A large clast at the upper part.
